I think the main thing is to be careful about what games you buy if the device will be worth it to you in the end, or if you are excited about upcoming games.  I waited to purchase the Switch until I knew there were about ten games I wanted to play and added about three of them into the in initial cost as well. Zelda breath of the wild‚Äîwhich I borrowed from my brother later‚Äî is more intensive than anything I have played in YEARS.Games are expensive in physical format, although that is my preference.  There are some cheaper games on the online store.  So far my favorite local game shop does not have any used copies of Switch games although they have everything else. I grew up playing Super NES, Nintendo 64, and Gameboy. The Switch is essentially all three of those systems wrapped into one. While traveling, I use the Switch exclusively in handheld mode. Obviously, upgrading to better controllers would be more comfortable but it isn't impossible to play without the pro controller.The games are expensive but that is the case for new PS4 or Xbox games as well. Take advantage of the free games that you can download through the Nintendo Store (there are videos reviewing them on YouTube all of the time). I've been able to find cheaper games at GameStop. The longer the Switch is out, the easier it will be to find used games.There are some limitations to the online playability with the Switch. My understanding is that you'll need to join Nintendo Switch Online ($20 a year) in order to play most games online. My only big complaint is that the controllers when in handheld mode don't always feel securely attached to the sides of the console. There is a small amount of wiggle if you move the console that is not really enough to bog down the experience, but is still noticeable enough to feel sort of cheap. Overall though this is a great console for a busy young adult still trying to find time for their favorite hobby and I highly reccomend it if you're interested.
